A FARM, of about s. acres situated in Millcreek
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight from Whining
ton, OF which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, well set with orchard grass
and clover. The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, 81 by "a feet. two stories high,
sith three rooms on The first floor, and four on
the second, with good cellar under the whole
Ia frame Barn, celared under, SO by 80 feet
Stone ,Toincrs shop and Gorncrib, 25 BY II
feet, and a stone Smokc-housc, all Of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality o
the land is well adapted for farming or grazing,
and has been we'll lined; it is in good neigh
bourhood, near several places ofpublic worship,
is in good neighboulhood for Mills, and within
two miles of good Limestone quarry. There is


likewise, Young thrifty Apple Orchard, and =
Peach Orchard, and the land is well watered
with good springs. For further particulars en-
qure of JosGPu BnINGnrnsr, Wilmington, or on
the Fam, OF JOHN FERRIS.

THE Subscriber takes this opportunity to in
form the public, that the establishment hereto
fore conducted by James Ran Esq, together
with the accounts connected with the business
of that establishment from the first Of January,
1926 have passed into his hands; and that he
will continue the business in all its branches, at
the Oh Stand, corner of 'ratnall and Gu en-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,
.NuH and D,pt CANDIES, Futier's, Yeilow and

When stable is ventilated by means ofa tube
or chimney, it should be placed in the centre of
the ceiling, the opening in which should be large,
in proportion to the number of horses kept; 1t
cannot well be too large, but it may be contract
| ed upwards, so as to leave concal shape, or 1t
may be made so as to resemble a dome cupo-
la. II should be carried few feet above the
| top Of the roof, and have lateral openings by
meaHs of slantng boards, but closed on the tops
by which contrivance, there would be free
communication with the atmosphere, and the
rain would be effectually excluded.


| There have been different opinions held with
respect to the removal of the litter during the
day: but when we consider how rapidly and a
bundant.y ammonia or the volatile akal is gen
Grated in it, and how injurious that yapour is to
the eyes and lungs, there can be no doubt OF the
propriety of removing it. DR.. Egan OF Dublin
has discovered according to Mr.. Peale, that the
urine of the horse begins to generate volatile
alkali very soon after It is yolded: and It is well
observed, by the same author, that IT this vapour
be capable ofpainfully stimulating sound and
healthy eye, its effects upon one that IS lntiam-
ed, and consequently, extremely irritable, must
be both highly painful and prejudicial to the or
gan. In confirmation Of this opinion, the author
relates the following experiment; A horse la
bouring under inflammation OF the eye, was Iemoy-
| ed from the stable, where he Kept ms eyes con
stanty shut and placed in COO, AIRY situation; IN
the space of half an hour he began gradually to
open his eyes, and, in the space 1.-TWO or three
hours, he kept them open boldly. The horse
was again placed in the stable, and in few min
utes he began gradually to close his eyes, and
after an hour or two, kept them constantly shut.
Not satisfied, however, with this experiment,
though it seems pretty conclusive, the horse was
again removed to the cool situation, and the same
effect followed rs at first. II the vapours pro
duced by foul litter prove SO injurious to the
eyes, it cannot surely be less prejudicial to the
lungs; and it is highly probable !hat if coughs
are not produced in this way they are often az
grayated and rendered incurable by those lil'tat-
ing etiluvia.-Another evil to be considered is
the propensity observable in many horses TO cat
their litter This is often the case with such as
have chronic cough, or are disposed to become
broken wnded, or have worms; and in all these
diseases, there is nothing, perhaps moro likely
to increase them than the animals eating foul
litter. l. must be obvious that horses employ
cd in severe labour should be allowed to, lie
down whenever they are inclined 10 do so but
event then, all their litter may be turned out car
~ in the morning, the floor of the stall swept
perfectly clean, and bed OF fresh straw put in.
1t the foul litter be spread abroad in the open ar
and shaken up two or three times during the day,
the greater part would be again fit for litter and,
~
serve TO replace that upon which the horse has
rested during the day. It has been said, that
horses which stand constantly on litter are apt 10
feel the difference Of the rOatl and become ten
der-footed. Mr. CLARK observes that the heat
arising from the litter occasions a more than or
dinary derivation Of blood to the legs and fcct,-
and hence arise swelling or gourdiness Of those
( parts, greasy heels, and stiffness or nunbness.
! ifthe horse lies down for relief, the heat of the
litter soon forces him to get up again, and after
repeatedly lying down, and forced to get up i'm
mediately from the above cause, he attempts it
no further; he stands upright, or perhaps little
straddllng, often shifting the weight of his body
| from one leg to the other. This erect position,
| in which he is obliged to stand, increases the
swengs in his legs, &c. and recourse is then
had to bleeding, purging, diurctics, &c.


Lord Pembroke, in his Military Equitation, OBJ


serves that after working, and at night Of course,
as also IN lameness and sickness, il is good for
horses to stand on litter; it also produces stang
&c. At other times it is bad custom; the con.
stant use oft heats and makes the feet tender,
and causes swe|ed legs moreover, it renders
| the animal delicate


! Swclled legs may be often reduced to their
natural size, merely by taking away tile litter,
which, in some stables, where ignorant grooms
and farrers govern, would be a great saving of
physic and bleeding, besides straw


| Lord Pembroke noticed by repeated expert
ments, that legs or unswell by leaving litter
or taking it away, like mercury in weather
glass. Mr.. Blaine is ofopinion, that the custom
4 of standing on litter ruins more horses than all
the mail and stage coaches put together; that it
is the fruitful source of contracted feet, and


brings on that r,nnous affection with more Ger
tainty than the hardest ork In nv own sta


bles Che says) no litter is suffered to remain


under the forefcet during the day. The horses


stand on bare bricks, which, in summer arc wa


tered to make them more cool; by which means
have experienced astonishing benefit. iehind


little litter is sstrewed, because they are apt 10


kick and break the bricks with their hind feet;
and because the litter thus placed sucks up tho
! moisture Of the Urine, which would be tletrmen-
tai to the hinder feet which are more liable ia


thrushes than contraction.





.4necdote.-When Sir Richard Steele was
: fitting up his great room in York buildings,
for public orations, he happened at that time
to be pretty much behind in the payment oi
. his workmen, and coming one day among
them to see how they went forward, he or.
dered one OF them to get up into the rostrum


and make a speech that he might observe
r how it could be heard The fellow mount
: ed, and scratching his pate, told him he knew
: not what to say, for in truth he was no orator
c OH said the knight mo matter for that. saw

ON THE MANAGEMENT AND DISEASES


OF HORSES.
TUE STABLE.

At HAVING lHSli Jtot dIltRSQ " OcdTlHR
state. felt an unwilingness to yield it up
to such an apparently insignificant foe with
out conflict; therefore in the years 1903
and 1909, tarred my trees with care and
perseverance. In the same years my neigh
bours generally used the same weapon of
defence; but there were few exceptions.
And when the foliage of the apple tree made
its appearance in the spring of 1910, it was
found that those trees which were not tarr-
ed, and those trees which were tarred, wei e
alike freed from the rayages Of the canker
worm.


The cause of their sudden exit was attrib-
uted by some to severe storm which fell
Immediately after the worms had taken their
station on the leaves, and while they were
extremely small and tender; but whatever
the cause might be, this is certain, that we
have experienced no great harm from them
until the present year, nor is the damage
great and universal in this vicinity; yet it is
sufficient to give the alarm and teach us
that we must again have recourse to the
means Of an exterminating war, or suffer
the consequences which will result from
sloth and neglect


Although it may in truth be said that fif-
teen or sixteen years have elapsed. during
WHICH time there has been no actual neLes-
sity for the owners OF orchards standing in
hostile array against the canker worm; yet
the fact is there has not been single year
since 1910 but have discovered the enemy
in my orchard, and he is in some others,
lurking upon the trees. have also for the
last three years discovered gradual in
crease of their numbers; but / should have
supposed their numbers to have increased
during the last year at least four fold.
recollect having read, several years since.
in one of the Boston newspapers, the result
of an experiment used as preventive a
ganst the canker worm, which was, to the
best Of my recollection, in substance as fol-
lows.


A quantity of lime was collected from the
sweeping OF a lime store, and spread on the
ground around a certain apple tree, some
time in the month of November, the foliage
of which tree had been destroyed BY the can
ker worm the preceding summer, the ground
at the time being in pulveri2ed state, the
lime was spread as far from the trunk Of
the tree as the droppings from the branches
extended; the effect was stated 70 be, the
entire disappearance of the worm, and an in
creased vigor of the tree.


now mention this wholly from memory,
and in the hope that there may be some
one whois acquainted with the fact who will
have the goodness to give the details to the
puDllc.


To use tar as preventive with complete
effect, my experience teaches me, is a long
and tedious process, and from which if anv
other means can be devised equally as eff
cacious, equally cheap and more expeditions,
confess should be glad to have an exemp-
tion. 1t has been found necessary in some
years in the tarring process to commence
the operation in the month of November
and if an orchard be planted on warm soil
and on southern declivity, the grub has
been found to be on its march every warm
evening from November, to some time in
April, provided they be not impeded by fro
2cn ground.


have seen great numbers caught in Feb
ruary; and the same year it was necessary
to tar from that time until the middle oi
April, every evening when the state of the
atmosphere was so warm that the grount
did not become frozen by sunset. To those
however, who may have occasion to tai
their orchards the year ensuing, and whc
choose to travel i'll the old and generally
approved track, would recommend the ap
plication of two or three dressings of tar Il
their trees at proper intervals, about the pc
riod OF the Matching of the worms, or yer,
soon after; as experience has discovered
that when the female grub is defeated il
ner purpose OF ascending the tree, anc
there dcpositing her eggs on the branches
she will deposit them within the loose bark
OF the trunk, and thus perpetuate her proge
ny; and to limited extent defeat the ex
pectations Of those who make use of tar as
preventive. One other means of prevep
tion in degree sufficient to preserve th
fruit from the ravages Of the canker worn,
will mention, as there are yet several per
sons living who will attest the tact.


From thirty to forty years ago the canke
worm prevailed very generally in this vi
cnity, during the whole of those years.
some person. tarred their trees, but tn
greater part did not at that time one &
my neighbors had an orchard which was di
vided by road 80 feet wide; on one side {
the road he planted potatoes every year.
on the other it was generally in grass;-tha
portion OF his orchard which was plante
with potatoes, yielded every other year
very handsome supply OF apples (the tree
being all OF one kind under any circumstar
ces never bore every Year, while that po,
ton of his orchard that was in grass WI
from year to year stripped of every gree
leaf. until at length it became exhausts
with its efsrts to produce two generation
Of leaves year, for so many years in SUI
cession; the trees became tired of the effo
and perished.

fitting up his great room in York buildings,
for public orations, he happened at that time
to be pretty much behind in the payment Of
his workmen, and coming one day among
them to see how they went forward, he or.
dered one of them to get up into the rostrum
and make a speech that he might observe
how it could BE heard. The fellow mount
| ed, and scratching his pate, told him he knew

OH said the knight, mo matter for that: say
any thing that comes uppermost.' why
here, Sir Richard,' says the man, we have

and cannot get one penny Of money; pray
sir, when do you mean to pay lis" Very
we'll, very we'll, said Sir Richard 'prav

Industry and fccommodation.-A cobler
OF Black Rock, advises "barefooted people
and those with old buks on their trotters,
to present their cases briefly to him for ex-
animation, and they will be e-shod, repair
ed, re-soled, -vamped, re-quartered, or re-
lifted, at their liking" and, Gas "a stitch i,


time saves nlne,' he will, with proper mott
fcation, rise any time of night to repair {


rip"


.fhroftabie zoife.-Ve are informed tina


there is a farmer in the town of b, il
Hampden county, Conn. who keeps "a COWS
and makes great quantities of bntter ant


cheese, with no other help than his wife
He has no children, and hires no laborer ex
cept in the time of hay making; during tina
busy season his wife brings the "a COWS fron


the pasture. milks them all herself, make


the cheese, takes care one or two tons G


cheese on the shelves, and does the cooking


washing and other work of the family.

A FARM, of about s. acres situated in Millcreek
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight from Whining
ton, OF which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, well set with orchard grass
and clover. The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, 81 by "a feet. two stories high,
sith three rooms on The first floor, and four on
the second, with good cellar under the whole
Ia frame Barn, celared under, SO by 80 feet
Stone ,Toincrs shop and Gorncrib, 25 BY II
feet, and a stone Smokc-housc, all Of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality o
the land is well adapted for farming or grazing,
and has been we'll lined; it is in good neigh
bourhood, near several places ofpublic worship,
is in good neighboulhood for Mills, and within
two miles of good Limestone quarry. There is


likewise, Young thrifty Apple Orchard, and =
Peach Orchard, and the land is well watered
with good springs. For further particulars en-
qure of JosGPu BnINGnrnsr, Wilmington, or on
the Fam, OF JOHN FERRIS.

full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, tho
18th inst, an indentcd boy to the Coachmaking
business, named JOHN HAIL. he vert in com
pany with boy bound 10 Thomas Moore. He
is about l9 years Of age, about five feet sixinches
high, thick SCI; speaks quick when spoken to-;
has rather a down look; light hair and light com
plcYon--had on when he went way, suit o
blue clothes, fur hat, and boots.


Whoever Will secure the boy in any Jail, SO
that | can get hin again, Shall receive the above
reward together with reasonable charges if
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harLorng said boy, at their peril.


PETER A. HUMPHREYS.


Wilmington, Del. Jan 25-l9 Al.

full articles.article:
THE Subscriber takes this opportunity to in
form the public, that the establishment hereto
fore conducted by James Ran Esq, together
with the accounts connected with the business
of that establishment from the first Of January,
1926 have passed into his hands; and that he
will continue the business in all its branches, at
the Oh Stand, corner of 'ratnall and Gu en-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House, where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,
.NuH and D,pt CANDIES, Futier's, Yeilow and
Bfotca S0lP, Of the best quality.

vance. 1t will be sent to any part of the United

full articles.headline:
ON THE MANAGEMENT AND DISEASES


OF HORSES.
full articles.article:
liz . hDhIi'


When stable is ventilated by means ofa tube
or chimney, it should be placed in the centre of
the ceiling, the opening in which should be large,
in proportion to the number of horses kept; 1t
cannot well be too large, but it may be contract
| ed upwards, so as to leave concal shape, or 1t
may be made so as to resemble a dome cupo-
la. II should be carried few feet above the
| top Of the roof, and have lateral openings by
meaHs of slantng boards, but closed on the tops
by which contrivance, there would be free
communication with the atmosphere, and the
rain would be effectually excluded.


| There have been different opinions held with
respect to the removal of the litter during the
day: but when we consider how rapidly and a
bundant.y ammonia or the volatile akal is gen
Grated in it, and how injurious that yapour is to
the eyes and lungs, there can be no doubt OF the
propriety of removing it. DR.. Egan OF Dublin
has discovered according to Mr.. Peale, that the
urine of the horse begins to generate volatile
alkali very soon after It is yolded: and It is well
observed, by the same author, that IT this vapour
be capable ofpainfully stimulating sound and
healthy eye, its effects upon one that IS lntiam-
ed, and consequently, extremely irritable, must
be both highly painful and prejudicial to the or
gan. In confirmation Of this opinion, the author
relates the following experiment; A horse la
bouring under inflammation OF the eye, was Iemoy-
| ed from the stable, where he Kept ms eyes con
stanty shut and placed in COO, AIRY situation; IN
the space of half an hour he began gradually to
open his eyes, and, in the space 1.-TWO or three
hours, he kept them open boldly. The horse
was again placed in the stable, and in few min
utes he began gradually to close his eyes, and
after an hour or two, kept them constantly shut.
Not satisfied, however, with this experiment,
though it seems pretty conclusive, the horse was
again removed to the cool situation, and the same
effect followed rs at first. II the vapours pro
duced by foul litter prove SO injurious to the
eyes, it cannot surely be less prejudicial to the
lungs; and it is highly probable !hat if coughs
are not produced in this way they are often az
grayated and rendered incurable by those lil'tat-
ing etiluvia.-Another evil to be considered is
the propensity observable in many horses TO cat
their litter This is often the case with such as
have chronic cough, or are disposed to become
broken wnded, or have worms; and in all these
diseases, there is nothing, perhaps moro likely
to increase them than the animals eating foul
litter. l. must be obvious that horses employ
cd in severe labour should be allowed to, lie
down whenever they are inclined 10 do so but
event then, all their litter may be turned out car
~ in the morning, the floor of the stall swept
perfectly clean, and bed OF fresh straw put in.
1t the foul litter be spread abroad in the open ar
and shaken up two or three times during the day,
the greater part would be again fit for litter and,
~
serve TO replace that upon which the horse has
rested during the day. It has been said, that
horses which stand constantly on litter are apt 10
feel the difference Of the rOatl and become ten
der-footed. Mr. CLARK observes that the heat
arising from the litter occasions a more than or
dinary derivation Of blood to the legs and fcct,-
and hence arise swelling or gourdiness Of those
( parts, greasy heels, and stiffness or nunbness.
! ifthe horse lies down for relief, the heat of the
litter soon forces him to get up again, and after
repeatedly lying down, and forced to get up i'm
mediately from the above cause, he attempts it
no further; he stands upright, or perhaps little
straddllng, often shifting the weight of his body
| from one leg to the other. This erect position,
| in which he is obliged to stand, increases the
swengs in his legs, &c. and recourse is then
had to bleeding, purging, diurctics, &c.


Lord Pembroke, in his Military Equitation, OBJ


serves that after working, and at night Of course,
as also IN lameness and sickness, il is good for
horses to stand on litter; it also produces stang
&c. At other times it is bad custom; the con.
stant use oft heats and makes the feet tender,
and causes swe|ed legs moreover, it renders
| the animal delicate


! Swclled legs may be often reduced to their
natural size, merely by taking away tile litter,
which, in some stables, where ignorant grooms
and farrers govern, would be a great saving of
physic and bleeding, besides straw


| Lord Pembroke noticed by repeated expert
ments, that legs or unswell by leaving litter
or taking it away, like mercury in weather
glass. Mr.. Blaine is ofopinion, that the custom
4 of standing on litter ruins more horses than all
the mail and stage coaches put together; that it
is the fruitful source of contracted feet, and


brings on that r,nnous affection with more Ger
tainty than the hardest ork In nv own sta


bles Che says) no litter is suffered to remain


under the forefcet during the day. The horses


stand on bare bricks, which, in summer arc wa


tered to make them more cool; by which means
have experienced astonishing benefit. iehind


little litter is sstrewed, because they are apt 10


kick and break the bricks with their hind feet;
and because the litter thus placed sucks up tho
! moisture Of the Urine, which would be tletrmen-
tai to the hinder feet which are more liable ia


thrushes than contraction.





.4necdote.-When Sir Richard Steele was
: fitting up his great room in York buildings,
for public orations, he happened at that time
to be pretty much behind in the payment oi
. his workmen, and coming one day among
them to see how they went forward, he or.
dered one OF them to get up into the rostrum


and make a speech that he might observe
r how it could be heard The fellow mount
: ed, and scratching his pate, told him he knew
: not what to say, for in truth he was no orator
c OH said the knight mo matter for that. saw

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the New-England Farmer.


CANKER WORM.
full articles.article:
At HAVING lHSli Jtot dIltRSQ " OcdTlHR
state. felt an unwilingness to yield it up
to such an apparently insignificant foe with
out conflict; therefore in the years 1903
and 1909, tarred my trees with care and
perseverance. In the same years my neigh
bours generally used the same weapon of
defence; but there were few exceptions.
And when the foliage of the apple tree made
its appearance in the spring of 1910, it was
found that those trees which were not tarr-
ed, and those trees which were tarred, wei e
alike freed from the rayages Of the canker
worm.


The cause of their sudden exit was attrib-
uted by some to severe storm which fell
Immediately after the worms had taken their
station on the leaves, and while they were
extremely small and tender; but whatever
the cause might be, this is certain, that we
have experienced no great harm from them
until the present year, nor is the damage
great and universal in this vicinity; yet it is
sufficient to give the alarm and teach us
that we must again have recourse to the
means Of an exterminating war, or suffer
the consequences which will result from
sloth and neglect


Although it may in truth be said that fif-
teen or sixteen years have elapsed. during
WHICH time there has been no actual neLes-
sity for the owners OF orchards standing in
hostile array against the canker worm; yet
the fact is there has not been single year
since 1910 but have discovered the enemy
in my orchard, and he is in some others,
lurking upon the trees. have also for the
last three years discovered gradual in
crease of their numbers; but / should have
supposed their numbers to have increased
during the last year at least four fold.
recollect having read, several years since.
in one of the Boston newspapers, the result
of an experiment used as preventive a
ganst the canker worm, which was, to the
best Of my recollection, in substance as fol-
lows.


A quantity of lime was collected from the
sweeping OF a lime store, and spread on the
ground around a certain apple tree, some
time in the month of November, the foliage
of which tree had been destroyed BY the can
ker worm the preceding summer, the ground
at the time being in pulveri2ed state, the
lime was spread as far from the trunk Of
the tree as the droppings from the branches
extended; the effect was stated 70 be, the
entire disappearance of the worm, and an in
creased vigor of the tree.


now mention this wholly from memory,
and in the hope that there may be some
one whois acquainted with the fact who will
have the goodness to give the details to the
puDllc.


To use tar as preventive with complete
effect, my experience teaches me, is a long
and tedious process, and from which if anv
other means can be devised equally as eff
cacious, equally cheap and more expeditions,
confess should be glad to have an exemp-
tion. 1t has been found necessary in some
years in the tarring process to commence
the operation in the month of November
and if an orchard be planted on warm soil
and on southern declivity, the grub has
been found to be on its march every warm
evening from November, to some time in
April, provided they be not impeded by fro
2cn ground.


have seen great numbers caught in Feb
ruary; and the same year it was necessary
to tar from that time until the middle oi
April, every evening when the state of the
atmosphere was so warm that the grount
did not become frozen by sunset. To those
however, who may have occasion to tai
their orchards the year ensuing, and whc
choose to travel i'll the old and generally
approved track, would recommend the ap
plication of two or three dressings of tar Il
their trees at proper intervals, about the pc
riod OF the Matching of the worms, or yer,
soon after; as experience has discovered
that when the female grub is defeated il
ner purpose OF ascending the tree, anc
there dcpositing her eggs on the branches
she will deposit them within the loose bark
OF the trunk, and thus perpetuate her proge
ny; and to limited extent defeat the ex
pectations Of those who make use of tar as
preventive. One other means of prevep
tion in degree sufficient to preserve th
fruit from the ravages Of the canker worn,
will mention, as there are yet several per
sons living who will attest the tact.


From thirty to forty years ago the canke
worm prevailed very generally in this vi
cnity, during the whole of those years.
some person. tarred their trees, but tn
greater part did not at that time one &
my neighbors had an orchard which was di
vided by road 80 feet wide; on one side {
the road he planted potatoes every year.
on the other it was generally in grass;-tha
portion OF his orchard which was plante
with potatoes, yielded every other year
very handsome supply OF apples (the tree
being all OF one kind under any circumstar
ces never bore every Year, while that po,
ton of his orchard that was in grass WI
from year to year stripped of every gree
leaf. until at length it became exhausts
with its efsrts to produce two generation
Of leaves year, for so many years in SUI
cession; the trees became tired of the effo
and perished.


Z

.4necdote-When Sir Richard Steele was
fitting up his great room in York buildings,
for public orations, he happened at that time
to be pretty much behind in the payment Of
his workmen, and coming one day among
them to see how they went forward, he or.
dered one of them to get up into the rostrum
and make a speech that he might observe
how it could BE heard. The fellow mount
| ed, and scratching his pate, told him he knew
not what to say, for in truth he was no orator.
OH said the knight, mo matter for that: say
any thing that comes uppermost.' why
here, Sir Richard,' says the man, we have
been working for you these twelve months,
and cannot get one penny Of money; pray
sir, when do you mean to pay lis" Very
we'll, very we'll, said Sir Richard 'prav
come down; / have heard enough; cannot
say but you speak very distinctly; but | do
not much admire the subject


Industry and fccommodation.-A cobler
OF Black Rock, advises "barefooted people
and those with old buks on their trotters,
to present their cases briefly to him for ex-
animation, and they will be e-shod, repair
ed, re-soled, -vamped, re-quartered, or re-
lifted, at their liking" and, Gas "a stitch i,


time saves nlne,' he will, with proper mott
fcation, rise any time of night to repair {


rip"


.fhroftabie zoife.-Ve are informed tina


there is a farmer in the town of b, il
Hampden county, Conn. who keeps "a COWS
and makes great quantities of bntter ant


cheese, with no other help than his wife
He has no children, and hires no laborer ex
cept in the time of hay making; during tina
busy season his wife brings the "a COWS fron


the pasture. milks them all herself, make


the cheese, takes care one or two tons G


cheese on the shelves, and does the cooking


washing and other work of the family.
Jan IS, 1927.
